oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wagon with mules
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Men and women wearing hats pose while sitting on or standing beside a mule wagon. They seem amused. Two men are wearing riverboat captain's hats. In the background, two African American men work with baled cotton.

By the time this picture was made, cotton had long been indispensable to the Southern economy. In antebellum times, plantation owners bought black slaves to harvest cotton. It was grueling work. Planters shipped millions of cotton bales bound for European ports in order to feed the booming foreign textile industry. Newly freed slaves and their descendants continued working cotton as sharecroppers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mules; Carts & wagons; Cotton
